Towards scalable and non-IID robust
Hierarchical Federated Learning via Label-driven Knowledge Aggregator

Minh-DuongÂ Nguyen Pusan National University Q.-VietÂ Pham Pusan National University Dinh Thai Hoang University of Technology Sydney Long Tran-Thanh University of Warwick DiepÂ N.Â Nguyen University of Technology Sydney Won-Joo Hwang Corresponding author. Pusan National University
Abstract

In real-world applications, Federated Learning (FL) meets two challenges: (1) scalability, especially when applied to massive IoT networks, and (2) how to be robust against an environment with heterogeneous data. Realizing the first problem, we aim to design a novel FL framework named Full-stack FL (F2L). More specifically, F2L utilizes a hierarchical network architecture, making extending the FL network accessible without reconstructing the whole network system. Moreover, leveraging the advantages of hierarchical network design, we propose a new label-driven knowledge distillation (LKD) technique at the global server to address the second problem. As opposed to current knowledge distillation techniques, LKD is capable of training a student model, which consists of good knowledge from all teachersâ€™ models. Therefore, our proposed algorithm can effectively extract the knowledge of the regionsâ€™ data distribution (i.e., the regional aggregated models) to reduce the divergence between clientsâ€™ models when operating under the FL system with non-independent identically distributed data. Extensive experiment results reveal that: (i) our F2L method can significantly improve the overall FL efficiency in all global distillations, and (ii) F2L rapidly achieves convergence as global distillation stages occur instead of increasing on each communication cycle.

1 Introduction

Recently, Federated Learning (FL) is known as a novel distributed learning methodology for enhancing communication efficiency and ensuring privacy in traditional centralized one McMahan etÂ al. (2017). However, the most challenge of this method for client models is non-independent and identically distributed (non-IID) data, which leads to divergence into unknown directions. Inspired by this, various works on handling non-IID were proposed in Li etÂ al. (2020); Acar etÂ al. (2021); Dinh etÂ al. (2021a); Karimireddy etÂ al. (2020); Wang etÂ al. (2020); Zhu etÂ al. (2021); Nguyen etÂ al. (2022b). However, these works mainly rely on arbitrary configurations without thoroughly understanding the modelsâ€™ behaviors, yielding low-efficiency results. Aiming to fulfil this gap, in this work, we propose a new hierarchical FL framework using information theory by taking a deeper observation of the modelâ€™s behaviors, and this framework can be realized for various FL systems with heterogeneous data. In addition, our proposed framework can trigger the FL system to be more scalable, controllable, and accessible through hierarchical architecture. Historically, anytime a new segment (i.e., a new group of clients) is integrated into the FL network, the entire network must be retrained from the beginning. Nevertheless, with the assistance of LKD, the knowledge is progressively transferred during the training process without information loss owing to the empirical gradients towards the newly participated clientsâ€™ dataset.

The main contributions of the paper are summarized as follows. (1) We show that conventional FLs performance is unstable in heterogeneous environments due to non-IID and unbalanced data by carefully analyzing the basics of Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD). (2) We propose a new multi-teacher distillation model, Label-Driven Knowledge Distillation (LKD), where teachers can only share the most certain of their knowledge. In this way, the student model can absorb the most meaningful information from each teacher. (3) To trigger the scalability and robustness against non-IID data in FL, we propose a new hierarchical FL framework, subbed Full-stack Federated Learning (F2L). Moreover, to guarantee the computation cost at the global server, F2L architecture integrates both techniques: LKD and FedAvg aggregators at the global server. To this end, our framework can do robust training by LKD when the FL process is divergent (i.e., at the start of the training process). When the training starts to achieve stable convergence, FedAvg is utilized to reduce the serverâ€™s computational cost while retaining the FL performance. (4) We theoretically investigate our LKD technique to make a brief comparison in terms of performance with the conventional Multi-teacher knowledge distillation (MTKD), and in-theory show that our new technique always achieves better performance than MTKD. (5) We validate the practicability of the proposed LKD and F2L via various experiments based on different datasets and network settings. To show the efficiency of F2L in dealing with non-IID and unbalanced data, we provide a performance comparison and the results show that the proposed F2L architecture outperforms the existing FL methods. Especially, our approach achieves comparable accuracy when compared with FedAvg (McMahan etÂ al. (2017)) and higher 7âˆ’20%7percent207-20\% in non-IID settings.

2 Related Work

2.1 Federated Learning on non-IID data

To narrow the effects of divergence weights, some recent studies focused on gradient regularization aspects Li etÂ al. (2020); Acar etÂ al. (2021); Dinh etÂ al. (2021a); Karimireddy etÂ al. (2020); Wang etÂ al. (2020); Zhu etÂ al. (2021); Nguyen etÂ al. (2022b). By using the same conceptual regularization, the authors in Li etÂ al. (2020); Acar etÂ al. (2021), and Dinh etÂ al. (2021a) introduced the FedProx, FedDyne, and FedU, respectively, where FedProx and FedDyne focused on pulling clientsâ€™ models back to the nearest aggregation model while FedUâ€™s attempted to pull distributed clients together. To direct the updated routing of the client model close to the ideal server route, the authors in Karimireddy etÂ al. (2020) proposed SCAFFOLD by adding a control variate to the model updates. Meanwhile, to prevent the aggregated model from following highly biased models, the authors in Wang etÂ al. (2020) rolled out FedNova by adding gradient scaling terms to the model update function. Similar to Dinh etÂ al. (2021a), the authors in Nguyen etÂ al. (2022b) launched the WALF by applying Wasserstein metric to reduce the distances between local and global data distributions. However, all these methods are limited in providing technical characteristics. For example, Wang etÂ al. (2020) demonstrated that FedProx and FedDyne are ineffective in many cases when using pullback to the globally aggregated model. Meanwhile, FedU and WAFL have the same limitation on making a huge communication burden. Aside from that, FedU also faces a very complex and non-convex optimization problem.

Regarding the aspect of knowledge distillation for FL, only the work in Zhu etÂ al. (2021) proposed a new generative model of local users as an alternative data augmentation technique for FL. However, the majority drawback of this model is that the training process at the server demands a huge data collection from all users, leading to ineffective communication.

Motivated by this, we propose a new FL architecture that is expected to be more elegant, easier to implement, and much more straightforward. Unlike Dinh etÂ al. (2021a); Acar etÂ al. (2021); Karimireddy etÂ al. (2020), we utilize the knowledge from clientsâ€™ models to extract good knowledge for the aggregation model instead of using model parameters to reduce the physical distance between distributed models. Following that, our proposed framework can flexibly handle weight distance and probability distance in an efficient way, i.e., â€–pkâ€‹(y=c)âˆ’pâ€‹(y=c)â€–normsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘¦ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¦ğ‘\|p^{k}(y=c)-p(y=c)\| (please refer to AppendixÂ B).

2.2 Multi-Teacher Knowledge Distillation

MTKD is an improved version of KD (which is presented in AppendixÂ A.2), in which multiple teachers work cooperatively to build a student model. As shown in Zhu etÂ al. (2018), every MTKD technique solves the following problem formulation:

P1:minâ¡â„’mKL=âˆ‘r=1Râˆ‘l=1Cp^â€‹(l|ğ‘¿,ğr,T)â€‹logâ¡p^â€‹(l|ğ‘¿,ğğ’“,T)p^â€‹(l|ğ‘¿,ğg,T),:P1superscriptsubscriptâ„’ğ‘šKLsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘…ğ‘Ÿ1subscriptsuperscriptğ¶ğ‘™1^ğ‘conditionalğ‘™ğ‘¿superscriptğğ‘Ÿğ‘‡^ğ‘conditionalğ‘™ğ‘¿superscriptğğ’“ğ‘‡^ğ‘conditionalğ‘™ğ‘¿superscriptğğ‘”ğ‘‡\displaystyle\textbf{P1}:\min\mathcal{L}_{m}^{\textit{KL}}=\sum^{R}_{r=1}\sum^{C}_{l=1}\hat{p}(l|\bm{X},\bm{\omega}^{r},T)\log{\frac{\hat{p}(l|\bm{X},\bm{\omega^{r}},T)}{\hat{p}(l|\bm{X},\bm{\omega}^{g},T)}}, (1)

here, râˆˆ{R}ğ‘Ÿğ‘…r\in\{R\} are the teachersâ€™ indices. By minimizing P1, the student p^gsuperscript^ğ‘ğ‘”\hat{p}^{g} can attain knowledge from all teachers. However, when using MTKD, there are some problems in extracting the knowledge distillation from multiple teachers. In particular, the process of distilling knowledge in MTKD is typically empirical without understanding the teacherâ€™s knowledge (i.e., aggregating all KL divergences between each teacher and the student). Therefore, MTKD is unable to exploit teachersâ€™ detailed predictions for the KD (e.g., Liu etÂ al. (2020c), Asif etÂ al. (2019), Zhu etÂ al. (2018), Fukuda etÂ al. (2017), Tran etÂ al. (2020)). Another version of MTKD, KTMDs can only apply for a better teachers to distill knowledge (e.g., Shen etÂ al. (2019), Zhu & Wang (2021), Zhang etÂ al. (2022), Son etÂ al. (2021)). For example, as provided in (Shen etÂ al., 2019, eq.Â 6), the student only selects the best teacher to operate the knowledge distillation. Visually, this technique is the same as the way of selecting a teacher among a set of teachers to carry out a single teacher distillation. Therefore, the studentâ€™s performance is always bounded by the best teacherâ€™s performance. Another popular research direction in MTKD is to leverage the advantage of the gap between teachersâ€™ hidden class features. However, owing to the lack of explanatory knowledge in teachersâ€™ hidden layers, the method in Zhu & Wang (2021) cannot obtain better student performance when compared to their teachers. Generally, current MTKD techniques cannot extract good knowledge from different customer models, leading to weight divergence in FL.

3 Full-stack Federated Learning

3.1 The F2L framework

The main objective of our work is to design a hierarchical FL framework, in which a global server manages a set of distinct regional servers. Utilizing hierarchical FL, our proposed algorithm can achieve computation and computation efficiency. The reason is that Hierarchical FL makes the clients to train sectionally before making the global aggregation Liu etÂ al. (2020a); Briggs etÂ al. (2020). Consequently, FL inherits every advantage from mobile edge intelligence concept over traditional non-hierarchical networks (e.g., communication efficiency, scalability, controlability) Pham etÂ al. (2020); Luong etÂ al. (2016); Lim etÂ al. (2020). At the end of each knowledge-sharing episode, the regions (which are supervised by regional servers) cooperate and share their knowledge (each region functions as a distinguished FL system, with a set amount of communication rounds per episode).

In each episode, each region randomly selects a group of clients from the network to carry out the aggregation process (e.g., FedAvg, FedProx); therefore, each region functions as a small-scale FL network. As a result, there are always biases in label-driven performance by applying random sampling on users per episode (see AppendixÂ F). Given the random sampling technique applied to the regional client set, the regions always have different regional data distributions. Consequently, various label-driven performances of different teachers might be achieved.

At the global server, our goal is to extract good performance from regional teachers while maintaining the salient features (e.g., understanding of the regional data distributions) of all regions. As a result, we can capture useful knowledge from diverse regions in each episode using our proposed innovative knowledge distillation technique (which is briefly demonstrated in SectionÂ 3.2). We train the model on the standard dataset on the central server to extract knowledge from multiple teachers into the global student model. The preset data pool on the server ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} is used to verify the model-class reliability and generate pseudo labels.

The system model is illustrated in Fig.Â 1, and thoroughly described in AppendixÂ C.

The pseudo algorithm for F2L is demonstrated in AlgorithmÂ 1. When the FL process suffers from client-drift Karimireddy etÂ al. (2020) (i.e., the distribution of label-driven accuracies of different regions have large variance), the F2L framework applies LKD to reduce the class-wise performance gaps between regions (i.e., the regions with better performance on a particular class share their knowledge to regions with low performance). As a result, the FL network achieves a significantly faster convergence when utilizing LKD (which is intensively explained in SectionÂ 3.2.) for the global aggregation process. When the generalization gap between regions is considerably reduced (i.e., â€–maxrâ¡Î²rcâˆ’minrâ¡Î²rcâ€–â‰¤Ïµnormsubscriptğ‘Ÿsubscriptsuperscriptğ›½ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘Ÿsubscriptsuperscriptğ›½ğ‘ğ‘Ÿitalic-Ïµ\|\max_{r}{\beta^{c}_{r}}-\min_{r}{\beta^{c}_{r}}\|\leq\epsilon), our F2L network becomes vanilla FL to reduce computation and communication costs. To this end, our method can achieve computation efficiency while showing robustness to the non-IID data in the network. Additionally, whenever a new set of clients are added into the network and makes positive contributions to the FL system (e.g., â€–maxrâ¡Î²rcâˆ’minrâ¡Î²rcâ€–â‰¥Ïµnormsubscriptğ‘Ÿsubscriptsuperscriptğ›½ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘Ÿsubscriptsuperscriptğ›½ğ‘ğ‘Ÿitalic-Ïµ\|\max_{r}{\beta^{c}_{r}}-\min_{r}{\beta^{c}_{r}}\|\geq\epsilon where â€–maxrâ¡Î²rcâ€–normsubscriptğ‘Ÿsubscriptsuperscriptğ›½ğ‘ğ‘Ÿ\|\max_{r}{\beta^{c}_{r}}\| a corresponding to the new regionâ€™s performance) the LKD aggregator can be switched back to improve the FL systemâ€™s performance over again.

3.2 Label-driven Knowledge Distillation

To extract knowledge from multiple teachers to the global student model, we train the model on the standard dataset on the central server. The preset data pool on the server ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} is used to verify the model-class reliability and generate pseudo labels. In our work, the MTKD process executes two main tasks: (1) extracting the teachersâ€™ knowledge and (2) maintaining the studentsâ€™ previous performance.

3.3 Class Reliability Scoring

The main idea of class reliability variables Î²rcsubscriptsuperscriptğ›½ğ‘ğ‘Ÿ\beta^{c}_{r}, Î²ğoldcsubscriptsuperscriptğ›½ğ‘subscriptğold\beta^{c}_{\bm{\omega}_{\textit{old}}} in LKD is to weigh the critical intensity of the specific model. Therefore, we leverage the attention design from Vaswani etÂ al. (2017) to improve the performance analysis of teachersâ€™ label-driven.

For regional models with disequilibrium or non-IID data, the teachers only teach the predictions relying upon their specialization. The predictionâ€™s reliability can be estimated by leveraging the validation dataset on the server and using the function under the curve (AUC) as follows:

Î²rc=expâ€‹(fAUCc,râ€‹Tğ)âˆ‘r=1Rexpâ€‹(fAUCc,râ€‹Tğ),subscriptsuperscriptğ›½ğ‘ğ‘Ÿexpsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘“AUCğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘‡ğsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘…ğ‘Ÿ1expsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘“AUCğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘‡ğ\begin{split}\beta^{c}_{r}=\frac{\text{exp}(f_{\textit{AUC}}^{c,r}T_{\bm{\omega}})}{\sum^{R}_{r=1}\text{exp}(f_{\textit{AUC}}^{c,r}T_{\bm{\omega}})},\end{split} (7)

where fAUCc,rsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘ŸAUCf^{c,r}_{\text{AUC}} denotes the AUC function on classifier cğ‘c of the regional model rğ‘Ÿr. Since AUC provides the certainty that a specific classifier can work on a label over the rest, we use the surrogate softmax function to weigh the co-reliability among the same labeling classifiers on different teacher models. For simplicity, we denote Î²ğoldcsubscriptsuperscriptğ›½ğ‘subscriptğold\beta^{c}_{\bm{\omega}_{\textit{old}}} as the AUC on each labeling classifier:

Î²ğoldc=expâ€‹(fAUCc,ğoldâ€‹Tğ)expâ€‹(fAUCc,ğnewâ€‹Tğ)+expâ€‹(fAUCc,ğoldâ€‹Tğ).subscriptsuperscriptğ›½ğ‘subscriptğoldexpsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘“AUCğ‘subscriptğoldsubscriptğ‘‡ğexpsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘“AUCğ‘subscriptğnewsubscriptğ‘‡ğexpsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘“AUCğ‘subscriptğoldsubscriptğ‘‡ğ\begin{split}\beta^{c}_{\bm{\omega}_{\textit{old}}}=\frac{\text{exp}(f_{\textit{AUC}}^{c,\bm{\omega}_{\text{old}}}T_{\bm{\omega}})}{\text{exp}(f_{\textit{AUC}}^{c,\bm{\omega}_{\text{new}}}T_{\bm{\omega}})+\text{exp}(f_{\textit{AUC}}^{c,\bm{\omega}_{\text{old}}}T_{\bm{\omega}})}.\end{split} (8)

In the model update class reliability, instead of calculating the co-reliability between teachers, equationÂ 8 compares the performance of the previous and current global models. Moreover, we introduce a temperatured value for the class reliability scoring function, denoted as Tğsubscriptğ‘‡ğT_{\bm{\omega}}. By applying a large temperatured value, the class reliability variable sets Î²rcsubscriptsuperscriptğ›½ğ‘ğ‘Ÿ\beta^{c}_{r}, and Î²ğoldcsubscriptsuperscriptğ›½ğ‘subscriptğold\beta^{c}_{\bm{\omega}_{\textit{old}}} make a higher priority on the better performance (i.e., the label-driven performance on class cğ‘c from teacher rğ‘Ÿr, e.g., fAUCc,rsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘“AUCğ‘ğ‘Ÿf_{\textit{AUC}}^{c,r} in equationÂ equationÂ 7 or class cğ‘c from old model ğoldsubscriptğold\bm{\omega}_{\text{old}} in equationÂ equationÂ 8). By this way, we can preserve the useful knowledge which is likely ignored in the new distillation episode. The more detailed descriptions of class reliability scoring are demonstrated in AlgorithmÂ 6.

3.4 Joint Multi-teacher Distillation for F2L

We obtain the overall loss function for online distillation training by the proposed F2L:

â„’F2L=Î»1â€‹âˆ‘r=1Râ„’rKL+Î»2â€‹â„’ğupdKâ€‹L+Î»3â€‹â„’CEg,subscriptâ„’F2Lsubscriptğœ†1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘…ğ‘Ÿ1subscriptsuperscriptâ„’KLğ‘Ÿsubscriptğœ†2subscriptsuperscriptâ„’ğ¾ğ¿subscriptğupdsubscriptğœ†3subscriptsuperscriptâ„’ğ‘”CE\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{\text{F2L}}=\lambda_{1}\sum^{R}_{r=1}\mathcal{L}^{\textit{KL}}_{r}+\lambda_{2}\mathcal{L}^{KL}_{\bm{\omega}_{\textit{upd}}}+\lambda_{3}\mathcal{L}^{g}_{\textit{CE}}, (9)

where Î»1,Î»2,Î»3subscriptğœ†1subscriptğœ†2subscriptğœ†3\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2},\lambda_{3} are the scaling coefficients of the three terms in the joint loss function. The first and second terms imply the joint LKD from the regional teacher models and the updating correction step, respectively. Moreover, to ensure that knowledge the student receives from teachers is accurate and can be predicted accurately in practice, we need to validate the quality of the student model on the real data. Thus, we also compute the â€œstandardâ€ loss between the student and the ground-truth labels of the train dataset. This part is also known as the hard estimator, which is different from the aforementioned soft-distillator. The hard loss equation is as follows:

â„’CEgsubscriptsuperscriptâ„’ğ‘”CE\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{g}_{\textit{CE}} =Hâ€‹(y,p^â€‹(l|ğ‘¿,ğg,T))=âˆ‘l=1Cylâ€‹logâ¡p^â€‹(l|ğ‘¿,ğg,T).absentğ»ğ‘¦^ğ‘conditionalğ‘™ğ‘¿superscriptğğ‘”ğ‘‡subscriptsuperscriptğ¶ğ‘™1subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘™^ğ‘conditionalğ‘™ğ‘¿superscriptğğ‘”ğ‘‡\displaystyle=H(y,\hat{p}(l|\bm{X},\bm{\omega}^{g},T))=\sum^{C}_{l=1}y_{l}\log{\hat{p}(l|\bm{X},\bm{\omega}^{g},T)}. (10)

We use the temperature coefficient T=1ğ‘‡1T=1 to calculate the class probability for this hard loss. The overall training algorithm for LKD is illustrated in AlgorithmÂ 2. In terms of value selection for scaling coefficients, the old global model can be considered as an additional regional teacherâ€™s model in the same manner, in theory. Therefore, Î»2subscriptğœ†2\lambda_{2} should be chosen as:

Î»2={1Râ€‹Î»1,if update distillation in equationÂ 4Â is considered,0,otherwise,subscriptğœ†2cases1ğ‘…subscriptğœ†1if update distillation in equationÂ 4Â is considered,0otherwise\displaystyle\lambda_{2}=\begin{cases}\frac{1}{R}\lambda_{1},&\text{if update distillation in equation~{}\ref{LKD-OldNew-Loss-Weighted} is considered,}\\ 0,&\text{otherwise},\end{cases} (11)

where Rğ‘…R is the number of regions decided by our hierarchical FL settings. With respect to Î»3subscriptğœ†3\lambda_{3}, the value is always set as:

Î»3={1âˆ’R+1Râ€‹Î»1,if update distillation in equationÂ 4Â is considered,1âˆ’Î»1,otherwise.subscriptğœ†3cases1ğ‘…1ğ‘…subscriptğœ†1if update distillation in equationÂ 4Â is considered,1subscriptğœ†1otherwise\displaystyle\lambda_{3}=\begin{cases}1-\frac{R+1}{R}\lambda_{1},&\text{if update distillation in equation~{}\ref{LKD-OldNew-Loss-Weighted} is considered,}\\ 1-\lambda_{1},&\text{otherwise}.\end{cases} (12)

3.5 Discussions on the extent of protecting privacy

In its simplest version, our proposed F2L framework, like the majority of existing FL approaches, necessitates the exchange of models between the server and each client, which may result in privacy leakage due to, for example, memorization present in the models. Several existing protection methods can be added to our system in order to safeguard clients against enemies. These include adding differential privacy Geyer etÂ al. (2017) to client models and executing hierarchical and decentralized model fusion by synchronizing locally inferred logits, for example on random public data, as in work Chang etÂ al. (2019). We reserve further research on this topic for the future.

4 Experimental Evaluation

4.1 Comparison with FL methods

We run the baselines (see SectionÂ E) and compare with our F2L. Then, we evaluate the comparisons under different non-IID ratio. More precisely, we generate the IID data and non-IID data with two different Dirichlet balance ratio: Î±={1,10}ğ›¼110\alpha=\{1,10\}. The comparison results are presented in TableÂ 1. As shown in TableÂ 1, the F2L can outperform the four baselines with a significant increase in accuracy. The reason for this phenomenon is that the LKD technique selectively draws the good features from regional models to build a global model. Hence, the global model predicts the better result on each different class and the entire accuracy of the global model then increases tremendously. The significant impact when applying LKD to distill different teachers to one student is shown in TableÂ 2.

4.2 Computation Efficiency of F2L

To evaluate the computation efficiency of our proposed F2L process, we compare our F2L process with 3 benchmarks: (i) F2L-noFedAvg (aggregator only consists of LKD), (ii) vanilla FL (FL with flatten architecture and FedAvg as an aggregator), and (iii) flatten LKD (FL with flatten architecture based with LKD as an alternate aggregator). Fig.Â 2(a) shows that the F2L system can achieve convergence as good as the F2L-noFedAvg. The reason is that: after several communication rounds, the distributional distance between regions is reduced thanks to the LKD technique. Hence, the efficiency of the LKD technique on the data is decreased. As a consequence, the LKD technique shows no significant robustness over FedAvg aggregator. In the non-hierarchical settings, the flatten LKD and FedAvg reveal under-performed compared to the proposed hierarchical settings. We assume that the underperformance above comes from the data shortage of clientsâ€™ training models. To be more detailed, the clientsâ€™ dataset are considerably smaller than that of the \sayregional dataset. Thus, the regional models contain more information than the clientsâ€™ models. We believe that: in the LKD technique, teachersâ€™ models require a certain amount of knowledge to properly train a good student (i.e., the global model).

Given the convergence rate from Fig.Â 2(a) and the computation cost at the server on Fig.Â 2(b), we can see that, by using the adaptive switch between LKD and FedAvg in F2L, we can achieve significant computational efficiency at the aggregation server. Note that F2L can substantially increase performance and computation efficiency compared with non-hierarchical architecture.

4.3 Scalability

This section evaluates the F2L scalability. To do so, we inject a group of clients with non-IID data into our FL system after 100100100 rounds (when the convergence becomes stable). Note that the FL system has never trained these data. The detailed configurations of our experimental assessments can be found in AppendixÂ E. As it can be seen from Fig.Â 2(c), when a new group of clients are added to the FL system, the vanilla FL shows a significant drop in terms of convergence. The reason is because of the distribution gap between the global modelâ€™s knowledge and knowledge of the clientsâ€™ data. Whenever new data with unlearned distribution is added to a stable model, the model will make considerable gradient steps towards the new data distribution. Thus, the FedAvg takes considerable learning steps to become stable again. In contrast, in F2L system, the learning from newly injected regions does not directly affect the learning of the whole FL system. Instead, the knowledge from the new domains is selectively chosen via the LKD approach. Thus, the LKD process does not suffer from information loss when new clients with non-IID data are added to the FL system.

4.4 LKD Analysis

In this section, we evaluate the LKD under various settings to justify the capability of LKD to educate the good student from the normal teachers. Our evaluations are as follows.

Can student outperform teachers? To verify the efficiency of LKD with respect to enhancing student performance, we first evaluate F2L on MNIST, EMNIST, CIFAR-100100100, CINIC-101010, CelebA dataset. The regions are randomly sampled from the massive FL network. In this way, we only evaluate the performance of LKD on random teachers. TableÂ 2 shows top-1 accuracy on the regional teacher and student models. The results reveal that LKD can significantly increase the global model performance compared with that of the regional models. Moreover, the newly distilled model can work well under each regional non-IID data after applying the model update.


To make a better visualization for the LKDâ€™s performance, we reveal the result of LKD on EMNIST dataset in terms of confusion matrix as in Fig.Â 3. As it can be seen from the figure, the true predictions is represented by a diagonals of the matrices. A LKD performance is assumed to be well predicted when the value on diagonals is high (i.e., the diagonalsâ€™ colors is darker), and the off-diagonals is low (i.e., the off-diagonalsâ€™ colors are lighter). As we can see from the four figures, there are a significant reduce in the off-diagonalsâ€™ darkness in the student performance (i.e., Fig.Â 3(d)) comparing to the results in other teachers (i.e., FiguresÂ 3(a), 3(b), and 3(c)). Therefore, we can conclude that our proposed MTKD techniques can surpass the teachersâ€™ performance as we mentioned in SectionÂ 2.

Teachers can really educate student? We evaluate LKD under different soft-loss coefficients Î»1subscriptğœ†1\lambda_{1} while the hard-loss factor is set at Î»3=1âˆ’Î»1subscriptğœ†31subscriptğœ†1\lambda_{3}=1-\lambda_{1} (the scaling value Î»2subscriptğœ†2\lambda_{2} is set to 00). Thus, we can justify whether the robust performance of LKD comes from the joint distillation from teachers or just the exploitation of data-on-server training. We evaluate LKD on six scaling values Î»1={0,0.001,0.01,0.1,0.5,1}subscriptğœ†100.0010.010.10.51\lambda_{1}=\{0,0.001,0.01,0.1,0.5,1\}. We evaluate on three dataset, including EMNIST, CIFAR-10, and CIFAR-100, and summarize the results in TablesÂ 5, 6 and 7 in Appendices. We can see from the three tables that the LKD cap off with Î»3=0.01subscriptğœ†30.01\lambda_{3}=0.01. Especially, when Î»3=1subscriptğœ†31\lambda_{3}=1 (which means the LKD acts as a vanilla cross-entropy optimizer), the model accuracy reduces notably. This means that the LKD only uses hard-loss as a backing force to aid the distillation. Thus, our LKD is appropriate and technically implemented.

Required training sample size for joint distillation. To justify the ability of LKD under a shortage of training data, we evaluate LKD with six different data-on-server settings: Ïƒ={1,1/2,1/4,1/6,1/8,1/10}ğœ112141618110\sigma=\{1,1/2,1/4,1/6,1/8,1/10\}, where Ïƒğœ\sigma is the sample ratio when compared with the original data-on-server as demonstrated in TableÂ 4. As we can see from the implementation results in three TablesÂ 8, 9, and 10 in Appendices, the F2L is demonstrated to perform well under a relatively small data-on-server. To be more specific, we only need the data-on-server to be 444 times lower than the average data-on-client to achieve a robust performance compared with the vanilla FedAvg. However, we suggest using the data-on-server to be larger than the data from distributed clients to earn the highest performance for LKD. Moreover, due to the ability to work under unlabeled data, the data-on-server does not need to be all labeled. We only need a small amount of labeled data to aid the hard-loss optimizer. Thus, the distillation data on the server can be updated from distributed clients gradually.

Broader Impact and Limitation

Due to the hierarchical framework of our proposed F2L, each sub-region acts like an independent FL process. Therefore, our F2L is integrable with other current methods, which means that we can apply varying FL techniques (e.g., FedProx, FedDyne, FedNova, HCFL Nguyen etÂ al. (2022a)) into distinct sub-regions to enhance the overall F2L framework. Therefore, architecture search (e.g., which FL technique is suitable for distinct sub FL region) for the entire hierarchical network is essential for our proposed framework, which is the potential research for the future work. Moreover, the hierarchical framework remains unearthed. Therefore, a potentially huge amount of research directions is expected to be investigated (e.g., resource allocation Nguyen etÂ al. (2022c); Saputra etÂ al. (2022; 2021); Dinh etÂ al. (2021b), and task offloading in hierarchical FL Yang etÂ al. (2021)). However, our LKD technique still lacks of understanding about the teachersâ€™ models (e.g., how classification boundaries on each layer impact on the entire teachersâ€™ performance). By investigating in explainable AI, along with layer-wise performance, we can enhance the LKD, along with reducing the unlabeled data requirements for the distillation process in the future work.

5 Conclusion

In this research, we have proposed an FL technique that enables knowledge distillation to extract the-good-feature-only from clients to the global model. Our model is capable of tackling the FLâ€™s heterogeneity efficiently. Moreover, experimental evaluations have revealed that our F2L model outperforms all of the state-of-the-art FL baselines in recent years.

Appendix A Background

A.1 Stochastic Gradient Descent and Federated Learning

Consider an optimization on a Deep Neural Network (DNN) with the SGD algorithm and a set of parameters ğ={Ï‰1,Ï‰2,â€¦,Ï‰p}ğsubscriptğœ”1subscriptğœ”2â€¦subscriptğœ”ğ‘\bm{\omega}=\{\omega_{1},\omega_{2},\dots,\omega_{p}\} with pğ‘p being the size of the DNNâ€™s model. SGD Robbins & Monro (1951) usually uses a mini-batch gradient Woodworth etÂ al. (2020) g~â€‹(ğ)=âˆ’âˆ‡ğgbâ€‹(ğ)~ğ‘”ğsubscriptâˆ‡ğsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘ğ\widetilde{g}(\bm{\omega})=-\nabla_{\bm{\omega}}g_{b}(\bm{\omega}) instead of a full-batch gradient gâ€‹(ğ)=âˆ’âˆ‡ğfâ€‹(ğ)ğ‘”ğsubscriptâˆ‡ğğ‘“ğg(\bm{\omega})=-\nabla_{\bm{\omega}}f(\bm{\omega}). The subscript bğ‘b denotes the mini-batch index set, which is drawn from BğµB batches randomly. Therefore, in a mini-batch SGD, the full-batch dataset ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D} is divided into BğµB mini batches: ğ’Ÿ={ğ’Ÿ1,ğ’Ÿ2,â€¦,ğ’ŸB}ğ’Ÿsubscriptğ’Ÿ1subscriptğ’Ÿ2â€¦subscriptğ’Ÿğµ\mathcal{D}=\{\mathcal{D}_{1},\mathcal{D}_{2},\dots,\mathcal{D}_{B}\}. Thus, the mini-batch SGD satisfies:

gâ€‹(ğ)=1Bâ€‹âˆ‘b=1Bg~â€‹(ğ).ğ‘”ğ1ğµsubscriptsuperscriptğµğ‘1~ğ‘”ğ\begin{split}g(\bm{\omega})=\frac{1}{B}\sum^{B}_{b=1}{\widetilde{g}(\bm{\omega})}.\end{split} (13)

FL utilizes the concept of SGD. In terms of implicit optimization for FL, clients collect data in the areas which are under their supervision. Thus, data, collected by FL clients from each communication round, can act as a mini-batch of the SGD (the whole data in the FL system counts as the full-batch data) and contribute to the local training process on distributed clients. On completion of the local training at clients, the clients then send their local trained loss functions to the server for aggregation process McMahan etÂ al. (2017). The original idea of implicit optimization in FL is similar to the relationship between the full-batch and mini-batch gradients in equationÂ 13, which is as follows:

fâ€‹(ğ)=1Nâ€‹âˆ‘n=1Nfnâ€‹(ğ),ğ‘“ğ1ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘›1subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ\begin{split}f(\bm{\omega})=\frac{1}{N}\sum^{N}_{n=1}{f_{n}(\bm{\omega})},\end{split} (14)

where fâ€‹(ğ)ğ‘“ğf(\bm{\omega}) is the aggregated loss function at the server, and fnâ€‹(ğ)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğf_{n}(\bm{\omega}) is the resulting loss at the client nğ‘›n in the system with Nğ‘N clients. In order to simplify the FL process, the authors in McMahan etÂ al. (2017) proposed the surrogate function, namely FedAvg, in which the generality of the FL process is preserved:

ğ~=1Nâ€‹âˆ‘n=1Nğn.~ğ1ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘›1subscriptğğ‘›\begin{split}\widetilde{\bm{\omega}}=\frac{1}{N}\sum^{N}_{n=1}{\bm{\omega}_{n}}.\end{split} (15)

We have ğ~~ğ\widetilde{\bm{\omega}} to be the global parameter set that is aggregated from the set of Nğ‘N clients in the system. Due to the aforementioned similarities between SGD and FL, FL possesses all characteristics of the SGD.

A.2 Knowledge Distillation

Knowledge Distillation (KD) Hinton etÂ al. (2015) employs a technique to transfer the learned knowledge from a pre-trained teacher model to another model with less or similar complexity (student model). The model transfer process is implemented in two steps. In the first step, a surrogate output probability function, namely a temperature-softmax function, is utilized. By adding a temperature scaling variable Tğ‘‡T, the conventional softmax function then becomes:

p^â€‹(l|ğ‘¿,ğ,T)=expâ€‹(zlâ€‹(ğ‘¿)/T)âˆ‘j=1Cexpâ€‹(zjâ€‹(ğ‘¿)/T),^ğ‘conditionalğ‘™ğ‘¿ğğ‘‡expsuperscriptğ‘§ğ‘™ğ‘¿ğ‘‡subscriptsuperscriptğ¶ğ‘—1expsuperscriptğ‘§ğ‘—ğ‘¿ğ‘‡\begin{gathered}\hat{p}(l|\bm{X},\bm{\omega},T)=\frac{\text{exp}(z^{l}(\bm{X})/T)}{\sum^{C}_{j=1}\text{exp}(z^{j}(\bm{X})/T)},\end{gathered} (16)

where zjsuperscriptğ‘§ğ‘—z^{j} is the output set corresponding to class jğ‘—j of the given DNN with batch of input data ğ‘¿ğ‘¿\bm{X}. The subscript lğ‘™l denotes the index of softmax output which corresponds to the prediction on class lğ‘™l of the DNN. The intention of adding the variable Tğ‘‡T is to adjust the slope of the softmax function in the classifier as shown in equationÂ 16. As we can see, when we increase the value of Tğ‘‡T, the slope of the softmax function will decrease significantly. With large temperature scale values, over the same output range of data, the range of values represented by input zjsuperscriptğ‘§ğ‘—z^{j} is larger. Then, the output value tuple created by the teacher and student carries considerably more information. Therefore, the learning process between teacher and student is more effective.

In the second step, to help implement the transfer of knowledge from teacher to student, the authors in Hinton etÂ al. (2015) presented a new loss function, called distillation loss function (also known as soft-loss function). This loss function comprises two terms: the intrinsic entropy function of the teacher and the cross-entropy function between the teacher and the studentâ€™s outputs, which can be expressed as follows:

â„’KDsubscriptâ„’KD\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{\text{KD}} =Hâ€‹(pâ€‹(ğ‘¿),qâ€‹(ğ‘¿))âˆ’Hâ€‹(pâ€‹(ğ‘¿))=âˆ‘xiâˆˆğ‘¿pâ€‹(xi)â€‹logâ¡pâ€‹(xi)âˆ’âˆ‘xiâˆˆğ‘¿pâ€‹(xi)â€‹logâ¡qâ€‹(xi).absentğ»ğ‘ğ‘¿ğ‘ğ‘¿ğ»ğ‘ğ‘¿subscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘¿ğ‘subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘¿ğ‘subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–\displaystyle=H(p(\bm{X}),q(\bm{X}))-H(p(\bm{X}))=\sum_{x_{i}\in\bm{X}}{p(x_{i})\log{p(x_{i})}}-\sum_{x_{i}\in\bm{X}}{p(x_{i})\log{q(x_{i})}}. (17)

The purpose of this function is to compare the output distribution between teacher pâ€‹(ğ‘¿)ğ‘ğ‘¿p(\bm{X}) and student model qâ€‹(ğ‘¿)ğ‘ğ‘¿q(\bm{X}). In terms of information theory, this measurement shows the under-performance of the distribution set created by student, when the output distribution set of the teacher is taken as the sample distribution set, with precision of 100%percent100100\%. By minimizing this function, we reduce the functional difference between the two deep networks. As a result, the student model tends to make itâ€™s output distribution become more identical to the teacher modelâ€™s behavior.

Moreover, to restrain the student model from learning the teacherâ€™s false result, the authors in Hinton etÂ al. (2015) proposed the hard-loss formula:

â„’CEsubscriptâ„’CE\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{\text{CE}} =Hâ€‹(P,P^)=âˆ’âˆ‘xiâˆˆğ‘¿pâ€‹(xi)â€‹logâ¡p^â€‹(xi).absentğ»ğ‘ƒ^ğ‘ƒsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘¿ğ‘subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–^ğ‘subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–\displaystyle=H(P,\hat{P})=-\sum_{x_{i}\in\bm{X}}{p(x_{i})\log{\hat{p}(x_{i})}}. (18)

The hard-loss formula acts as a backing force with two main objectives. First of all, it ensures that the joint distillation function always follows the right optimizing track. Secondly, due to the highly complicated function made by the soft-loss function, the hard-loss force aids the model to escape the local minima whenever the model gets trapped. In this way, studentâ€™s training performance improves significantly.

Appendix B Issues about SGD and Federated Learning

As mentioned in AppendixÂ A.1, FL and SGD have the same attributes. Occasionally, SGD is an efficient method for DL. For a large dataset, SGD can converge faster as it causes updates to the parameters more frequently. Moreover, the steps taken towards the minima of the loss function have oscillations Shwartz-Ziv & Tishby (2017) that can help to get out of the local minima of the loss function Neelakantan etÂ al. (2015); Smith etÂ al. (2020); He etÂ al. (2019). Therefore, FL can operate well under the ideal conditions. However, when the problems, such as heterogeneity on data and high complexity on training models come about, both SGD and FL face many obstacles.

B.1 The generalization gap in SGD and FL

By measuring the distance between initial model and trained one, the research in Liu etÂ al. (2020b) manifests the proof of low distance traveled by the high complexity model using SGD. The authors observed that Vanilla SGD suffers from high overfitting compared to other training optimizing methods, such as data augmentation, Lâ€‹2ğ¿2L2-regularization, and momentum. Moreover, the modelâ€™s travelled distance which is trained by Vanilla SGD is 444 to 555 times lower than that is trained by the other methods. The research in Keskar etÂ al. (2016) shows that the lack of generalization ability is because large-batch methods tend to converge to sharp minimizers of the training function. These minimizers are characterized by a significant number of large positive eigenvalues in Hessian matrix of the loss function fâ€‹(ğ)ğ‘“ğf(\bm{\omega}), and tend to generalize less effectively. When considering each distributed node in the FL system as a mini-batch of SGD, we can imagine the current FL system as a large-batch for SGD, which can easily be trapped in the sharp minimum. For a more mathematical analysis, we consider the gradient dissimilarity inequality for the aggregated global model ğğ\bm{\omega}, there exist constants Gâ‰¥0ğº0G\geq 0 and Uâ‰¥1ğ‘ˆ1U\geq 1 that attain:

1Nâ€‹âˆ‘n=1Nâ€–âˆ‡fnâ€‹(ğ)â€–2â‰¤G2+U2â€‹â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ)â€–2,âˆ€ğ.1ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘›1superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ2superscriptğº2superscriptğ‘ˆ2superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“ğ2for-allğ\displaystyle\frac{1}{N}\sum^{N}_{n=1}{\|\nabla f_{n}(\bm{\omega})\|^{2}}\leq G^{2}+U^{2}\|\nabla f(\bm{\omega})\|^{2},~{}\forall\bm{\omega}. (19)

Here, we follow the heterogeneity assumption that GğºG is defined with gradient variance boundary (on client nğ‘›n) Ïƒn2subscriptsuperscriptğœ2ğ‘›\sigma^{2}_{n} as in Mishchenko etÂ al. (2019). Along with the condition that the problem fiâ€‹(ğ)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğf_{i}(\bm{\omega}) is Î¼ğœ‡\mu-smooth, the assumption can be relaxed as in Karimireddy etÂ al. (2020):

1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nâ€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ)â€–2âˆ’G2â‰ˆ1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nâ€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ)â€–2âŸğ”¸âˆ’2Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nâ€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğâˆ—)â€–2âŸğ”¹â‰¤2â€‹Î¼â€‹B2â€‹(fâ€‹(ğ)âˆ’fâˆ—),1ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘–1superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ2superscriptğº2subscriptâŸ1ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘–1superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ2ğ”¸subscriptâŸ2ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘–1superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptğ2ğ”¹2ğœ‡superscriptğµ2ğ‘“ğsuperscriptğ‘“\displaystyle\frac{1}{N}\sum^{N}_{i=1}{\|\nabla f_{i}(\bm{\omega})\|^{2}}-G^{2}\approx\underbrace{\frac{1}{N}\sum^{N}_{i=1}{\|\nabla f_{i}(\bm{\omega})\|^{2}}}_{\mathbb{A}}-\underbrace{\frac{2}{N}\sum\limits^{N}_{i=1}{\|\nabla f_{i}(\bm{\omega}^{*})\|^{2}}}_{\mathbb{B}}\leq 2\mu B^{2}(f(\bm{\omega})-f^{*}), (20)

where fâˆ—superscriptğ‘“f^{*} denotes the optimality. From this inequality, we can see that the distance between the current state fâ€‹(ğ)ğ‘“ğf(\bm{\omega}) and the global optima state fâˆ—superscriptğ‘“f^{*} is lower-bounded by ğ”¸+ğ”¹ğ”¸ğ”¹\mathbb{A}+\mathbb{B}. As we can see from equationÂ 20, the first term ğ”¸=1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nâ€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ)â€–2ğ”¸1ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘–1superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ2\mathbb{A}=\frac{1}{N}\sum^{N}_{i=1}{\|\nabla f_{i}(\bm{\omega})\|^{2}} reveals the average gradient norm at the model state ğğ\bm{\omega}. When this term of value is large, the current state is assumed to have a high chance to be far from the true optimal state fâˆ—superscriptğ‘“f^{*} (due to the term ğ”¹ğ”¹\mathbb{B} being fixed). Simultaneously, the current state ğğ\bm{\omega} is more likely to be a sharp minimizer because of a larger ğ”¸ğ”¸\mathbb{A} value. The illustrative explanation about sharp and flat minimizers is presented in Fig.Â 4.

Appendix C System Model

As shown in Fig.Â 1, we first compartmentalize the network into Rğ‘…R, where each region contains one access point (AP) acting as a local server (denoted by râˆˆ{1,2,â€¦,R}ğ‘Ÿ12â€¦ğ‘…r\in\{1,2,\dots,R\}) and Nğ‘N clients (denoted by nâˆˆ{1,2,â€¦,N}ğ‘›12â€¦ğ‘n\in\{1,2,\dots,N\}) are randomly sampled from the FL system. For each communication round of FL, those APs execute the FedAvg, which aggregates the model parameters from local predictors in their own regions, resulting in the regional aggregated model ğrsuperscriptğğ‘Ÿ\bm{\omega}^{r}. The global server receives the aggregated model parameters after a certain number of communication rounds. Each updated model, thus, acts as a teacher to share knowledge to the global deep model ğgsuperscriptğğ‘”\bm{\omega}^{g}. The data pool ğ’®=(ğ‘¿,ğ’€)={(xi,yi)}ğ’®ğ‘¿ğ’€subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–\mathcal{S}=(\bm{X},\bm{Y})=\{(x_{i},y_{i})\} in which iâˆˆ{1,2,â€¦,S}ğ‘–12â€¦ğ‘†i\in\{1,2,\dots,S\} is stored in the global server for the multi-teacher distillation process. Here, yiâˆˆ{1,2,â€¦,C}subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–12â€¦ğ¶y_{i}\in\{1,2,\dots,C\} is the truth label of the preset dataset ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S}. We define lğ‘™l as the output index of the deep model and câˆˆ{1,2,â€¦,C}ğ‘12â€¦ğ¶c\in\{1,2,\dots,C\} as the predicted label index of the data ğ‘¿ğ‘¿\bm{X} when it is processed by the deep model.

Appendix E Experiment Setup

Dataset. We evaluate all algorithms on non-IID data partitioning with Dirichlet random distribution function Li etÂ al. (2022). We use benchmark datasets with the same train/test splits as in McMahan etÂ al. (2017). We use four multi-class categorisation benchmark datasets in our evaluations, including 1) MNIST LeCun & Cortes (2010), 2) EMNIST Cohen etÂ al. (2017), 3) CIFAR-10 Krizhevsky (2009), 4) CIFAR-100 Krizhevsky (2009), 5) CINIC-10 Darlow etÂ al. (2018), and 6) CelebA gender classification Liu etÂ al. (2015) . The evaluation settings for simulations are listed in AppendixÂ M.

Settings. We apply two DNNs for our experimental evaluations, including LeNet-5 LeCun etÂ al. (1989) for MNIST and EMNIST datasets, and ResNet-181818 He etÂ al. (2016) for CIFAR-101010 and CIFAR-100100100. It is worth noting that we do not apply pre-trained models on both LeNet-555 and ResNet-181818 because the pre-trained models can help FL approach the global minima easily, which can reduce the generalization of the evaluation. The detailed settings is defined in AppendixÂ M

Baselines. We compare the performance on non-IID dataset with four baselines, including FedProx, FedDistill Chen & Chao (2020), FedGen Zhu etÂ al. (2021), and FedAvg.

Evaluation metric. We adopt top-1 accuracy on every experiments to evaluate the performance of our F2L method and the other FL baselines. Further, each evaluation is an average of five results.

Settings for Scalability test. We use CINIC-10 dataset, where the data consists of 270.000270.000270.000 images (90.00090.00090.000 images in each train, validation, test set). We use the train set for the FL training, validation set for the accuracy evaluation. To make the dataset for the additional clients, we use the test set. The more detailed of the settings is demonstrated in TableÂ 3. As described in TableÂ 3, the data on every client is sampled with non-IID coeff Î±=0.1ğ›¼0.1\alpha=0.1 (on both old and new regions). To make the test between FedAvg and F2L fair, we use the same number of users for added regions (i.e., total added clients is 100100100).

Appendix F Proof on Random Sampling effects to Data Distribution

Assumption 2

We consider the class-likelihood of an data as the classical Gaussian Mixture Model (GMM). Therefore, the feature distribution on data can be represented as the Dirichlet Process GMM (DPGMM) DelPozzo etÂ al. (2018).

pâ€‹(x|(Î¼c,Î£c,Ï€c)c=1C)=âˆ‘c=1CÏ€câ€‹ğ’©â€‹(ğ±;Î¼c,Î£c),ğ‘conditionalğ‘¥subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘subscriptÎ£ğ‘subscriptğœ‹ğ‘ğ¶ğ‘1subscriptsuperscriptğ¶ğ‘1subscriptğœ‹ğ‘ğ’©ğ±subscriptğœ‡ğ‘subscriptÎ£ğ‘\displaystyle p\left(x|(\mu_{c},\Sigma_{c},\pi_{c})^{C}_{c=1}\right)=\sum^{C}_{c=1}\pi_{c}~{}\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{x};\mu_{c},\Sigma_{c}), (22)

where Ï€csubscriptğœ‹ğ‘\pi_{c} is the Dirichlet allocation weight on class cğ‘c.

Lemma 3

The data distribution on regional FL is a combination of client set, and can be represented as a DPGMM.

pâ€‹(x|(Î¼c,Î£c,Ï€c)c=1C)=âˆ‘c=1CÎ±câ€‹ğ’©â€‹(ğ±;Î¼c,Î£c),ğ‘conditionalğ‘¥subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘subscriptÎ£ğ‘subscriptğœ‹ğ‘ğ¶ğ‘1subscriptsuperscriptğ¶ğ‘1subscriptğ›¼ğ‘ğ’©ğ±subscriptğœ‡ğ‘subscriptÎ£ğ‘\displaystyle p\left(x|(\mu_{c},\Sigma_{c},\pi_{c})^{C}_{c=1}\right)=\sum^{C}_{c=1}\alpha_{c}~{}\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{x};\mu_{c},\Sigma_{c}), (23)

Proof: The proof is demonstrate in AppendixÂ L.

To theoretically analyze the random sampling effects to regional data distribution, we need to prove that Ï€crâ‰ Ï€câ€²rsubscriptsuperscriptğœ‹ğ‘Ÿğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğœ‹ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘â€²\pi^{r}_{c}\neq\pi^{r}_{c^{\prime}} and Ï€crâ‰ Ï€crâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğœ‹ğ‘Ÿğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğœ‹superscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²ğ‘\pi^{r}_{c}\neq\pi^{r^{\prime}}_{c}. Covâ€‹(Ï€cr,Ï€crâ€²)=âˆ’Î½crâ€‹Î½crâ€²Î½Â¯2â€‹(Î½Â¯+1).Covsubscriptsuperscriptğœ‹ğ‘Ÿğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğœ‹superscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğœˆğ‘Ÿğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğœˆsuperscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²ğ‘superscriptÂ¯ğœˆ2Â¯ğœˆ1\displaystyle\mathrm{Cov}(\pi^{r}_{c},\pi^{r^{\prime}}_{c})=-\frac{\nu^{r}_{c}\nu^{r^{\prime}}_{c}}{\bar{\nu}^{2}(\bar{\nu}+1)}. As we can see from the two mentioned equations, the covariances Covâ€‹(Ï€cr,Ï€crâ€²)Covsubscriptsuperscriptğœ‹ğ‘Ÿğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğœ‹superscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²ğ‘\mathrm{Cov}(\pi^{r}_{c},\pi^{r^{\prime}}_{c}) and Covâ€‹(Ï€cr,Ï€câ€²r)Covsubscriptsuperscriptğœ‹ğ‘Ÿğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğœ‹ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘â€²\mathrm{Cov}(\pi^{r}_{c},\pi^{r}_{c^{\prime}}) is always lower than 00. Furthermore, when a system is suffered more seriously from non-IID, the concentration parameter (i.e., Î½crsubscriptsuperscriptğœˆğ‘Ÿğ‘\nu^{r}_{c}) becomes higher Hsu etÂ al. (2019). This phenomenon makes the random sampling capable of trigger high class-wise bias on regional FL. Therefore, the F2L can be more effective on heterogeneous network by applying LKD (which is more briefly described in 3.2).

Combining the aforementioned statement with equationÂ 2, we can decompose the KL divergence function into multiple sub-components as:

Although the same preset dataset is utilized on every teacher model, the different pseudo labeling judgments from different teachers lead to the different dataset tuples. The process of identifying Scrsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ğ‘ŸS_{c}^{r} is demonstrated in AlgorithmÂ 3. Because the regional models label on the same dataset Sğ‘†S, we have âˆ‘c=1CScr=Ssuperscriptsubscriptğ‘1ğ¶subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘†\sum_{c=1}^{C}S^{r}_{c}=S for all regional models. By dividing the dataset by class (regarding the teacherâ€™s label-driven prediction), we have the teacherâ€™s prediction as the pseudo label. Therefore, we can leverage the unlabeled dataset to train the LKD at the server. Moreover, with the decomposed equationÂ equationÂ 26, we can scale the point-wise distribution distance between two model rğ‘Ÿr, and gğ‘”g. Therefore, the scale can be leveraged to judge the teacher modelâ€™s label driven performance, and then, the good knowledge can be distilled. The surrogate MTKD function, so called LKD is demonstrated as follows:

Appendix L Proof on LemmaÂ 3
